Topic.Title: Let's see where shorts here will support her today.

Message.Msg: 1) What impact will Amazon cutting prices on AWS by 25% in response to Google's 20% cut (which then Google took off another 10%...) do to Amazon? And Google? 2) What will all the Fed printing do to Amazon's cost structure and relative cost structure over time? Unlike INTC, which is gaining leverage on previously made investments via its potential foundry deals with CSCO and AAPL, Amazon is cannibalizing Amazon direct sales with 3P... And, it is putting in new (relatively undifferentiated low ROIC) CapEx to service that business. It's easy to boost gross margins with malinvestment. The real question is what maximizes cash flow yield. INTC has it right, Amazon has it wrong... Geegee, who thinks the market moves up when he doesn't buy calls, calls others deranged... Topic.Title: Amazon is having a major setback on Kindle HD

Message.Msg: There are much bigger issues for Amazon. It simply does not have the "lock" on cloud services that everyone has suggested it did (else why would it cut prices by 25% when Google announced a 20% cut). That is the much hyped, formerly high margin growth business. 3P is a scam. The customer is already on the website when purchasing, thus Amazon has made the investing in customer acquisition and branding (see the non stop ads on TV). So, is Amazon better off selling its own product (where it captures all the value) or sharing with the 3P sellers? And, yet, it is building out non differentiated fulfillment centers (UPS already has a bigger better network) to handle that business. Inventory turns dropping. ROIC dropping. Operating cash flow hasn't grown in years. One giant scam...

Topic.Title: I was right about the company needing cash

Message.Msg: If you go back and look at my posts, I predicted Amazon would have to cancel monthly Prime. It would have allowed everyone to ship for free in the holiday season and cancel afterward, creating a cash flow issue. Needless to say, it did. It also raised debt not long after... I don't think Amazon is going to be insolvent (although there are several tail risk scenarios where it could...). But, it simply is NOT in a position to capture the value that all the pumpers have built into forecasts. Google's shopping model will win longer term. Its incentives are aligned with traditional retail. Amazon's is not.

Message.Msg: But until they let scams like this go and relative valuations make some sense, it will not happen. The reality is that people are buying ST duration treasuries, so there is little interest rate risk and no principal risk. When WS restores the credibility of the market by at least getting the relative valuations right and ending these algo float jam manipulation scams (and the converse is that companies like INTC are systematically held back...), the capital won't return. Trust is broken and must be restored. Taking markets higher simply allows investors to scale out and move money to safer places. Only when the games end will investors believe that the stock market is again about allocating capital to productive enterprise and not a casino... Until then...

But dont worry, the SEC has your back, and you'll alwayz get a crack at participating in a Class Action law suite to get a few cents / share back on what remainz after the attorneys polish off the scraps that guys like bezos and the bot havin momo's leave behind - thats surety.

Message.Title: Wake up fvck erz .... Now they just cancel the tradez if the rich dudez and their bots dont like 'em
Message.Msg: Another 'Flash crash' will be comming, the guy with the most money gets to determine the outcome of who winz and who losez - par for the course... Headlinez read: Nasdaq cancels pre-market trades in 9 big-cap stocks Reuters 12/13/2012 12:42 PM ET NEW YORK, Dec 13 (Reuters) - Stock exchange operator Nasdaq OMX (NDAQ) is cancelling a series of premarket trades that resulted in wild price swings in a number of stocks on Thursday, including Citigroup (C) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), the exchange said. Nasdaq said in a statement it is cancelling trades in nine stocks in which trades occurred at prices that marked a swing of 10 percent or more from Wednesday's closing prices. "We have no comment further than our ruling," said Robert Madden, a Nasdaq OMX (NDAQ) spokesman. Trades executed in the last minute of premarket trading on a third-party platform show wild swings in shares. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), for instance, closed on Wednesday at $14.53 a share. It saw more than 50 trades at $3.06 a piece, according to Thomson Reuters data. Dennis #$%$, market structure consultant and proprietary trader at Bright Trading in Detroit, said these types of flash crashes happen so frequently now that they've almost become the norm. "Basically an order was directed at Nasdaq, and it swept out the liquidity on that exchange. So, despite liquidity being there on other exchanges, that order didn't interact with that liquidity," he said. But busting trades creates a number of issues for investors, and damages investor confidence in market structure, he said. Other stocks affected by the cancellations include AT&T (T) , Wells Fargo (WFC), Western Union (WU), Kroger (KR), Ventas (VTR), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Sprint Nextel (S). Nasdaq said trades in the following stocks will stand: Hess , Reynolds American (RAI), Williams, Salesforce , IBM (IBM), Leucadia National (LUK) and Molson Coors (TAP/A) . Those stocks had also been listed in an announcement by Nasdaq of its investigation into potentially erroneous transactions just before the opening. (Reporting By David Gaffen; additional reporting by Caroline Valetkevitch; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama, Leslie Adler and David Gregorio)

Message.Title: Sales tax coming
Message.Msg: Wed Dec 12, 4:51 PM UTC Governors are urgently pressing Congress to pass Internet sales tax legislation in the coming weeks, saying states cannot afford to wait to collect billions of dollars from online retailers. Washington state Governor Chris Gregoire, a Democrat, and Tennessee Governor Bill Haslam, a Republican, wrote to Senate leaders on Tuesday urging them to pass legislation granting states the authority to collect sales taxes from online businesses. The letter was released on Wednesday. They said the changes should be made this year and not be wrapped into "wide-ranging, comprehensive tax reform" in 2013. Legislation requiring online retailers to collect and remit sales taxes to states has languished in the Senate and House of Representatives for years, but the issue has grown more pressing as U.S. shoppers increasingly buy goods online. The governors, writing on behalf of the National Governors Association, said states "are unable to collect $23 billion in sales taxes owed annually from remote sales," and that current practices are "in essence an unwarranted yet growing subsidy to Internet sellers at the expense of brick-and-mortar stores." Last week, hundreds of state legislators met with members of President Barack Obama's administration and the U.S. Congress about the so-called "fiscal cliff" of automatic austerity and tax increases. They also made the case for changing Internet sales soon. The lawmakers came away encouraged that federal legislation addressing sales taxes would soon be passed, with National Conference of State Legislatures Executive Director William Pound telling reporters he expects Congress to finish work on it in early 2013. The current bill in the Senate, known as the Marketplace Fairness Act, would give states authority to collect sales taxes from large businesses after they simplify their tax systems. Not all states collect sales taxes, and those that do vary in the rates and structures they use. The governors said it would help speed the economic recoveries of states, cities and counties without "raising taxes or increasing the federal debt."

All though the party haz been over for scamazon'z 7 losing qaurterly reports, this could be the nail in the coffin for this pig... Its no surprize that this waz comming and no big deal right now for the fmr manipulatorz of the pig stok, but it will turn into an incessant drum beat after this pig dumps 40% over night at some point , and then losez 85% of its high from there. There iz simply no foward looking metric of any type that can keep this pig flying... Its a joke.

If they understood the multiplier effect of lost tax revenue because the Amazon $ immediately flow out of the state rather than being recirculated in the local economy (thus reducing the local velocity of money) and generating more tax $, they'd be even more aggressive. Ultimately, they don't need a federal tax. If every state pension fund threatened to pull all direct and indirect investment in Amazon unless it collected taxes in every state, it would make the change tomorrow because it needs the artificially low cost of capital to survive with its economics...

Snyder should do this. It would be forward thinking and would reaffirm that his policies are Michigan business and worker friendly (supporting the companies that actually invest in Michigan rather than take from it). Anyone know Rick? :-)

Message.Title: aapl
Message.Msg: They will hold this up until one big desk decides to get a little jump on the sell side. if you think apple has dropped fast for no apparent reason watch when one of these hedges tries to get a little jump on the rest of them. I can easily see a 50 point one day drop with a hundred point 2 week blood bath. No one will get out when there will be big crowds and small exits. when it starts you won't be fast enough to the exit. As soon as someone gets wind that the costs for the 4th quarter are not going to produce bottom line growth, it will be a Katie Bar The Door moment.

Topic.Title: Here is an online retail IPO concept. Its ticker: SCAM

Message.Msg: Since none of these fundamentals matter, it really depends on who the pumpsters are and if they have big enough of a book to push the SCAM stock higher and higher. So who do you have in mind?

I wonder if any of the analysts are going to ask how about how much Amazon is spending on TV ads to generate the loss leading growth? Given that Kindles are sold at cost and Prime has significant content costs (again with unlimited movies, Prime is really just a bid to retain its digital books monopoly and capture some incremental music revenues). I wonder what the breakeven incremental physical goods and/or 3P sales are per commercial...
Just checking...
Being censored again.. Note the Re: Re: (I responded to my own post, which was immediately censored). Go figure.

I wonder what the breakeven is on all the new TV advertising? No profit on Kindle, Prime itself has significant content cost (and with unlimited free video, the only major incremental content revenue stream is music since Amazon already had a virtual monopoly on eBooks).

I guess it doesn't matter for Amazon since generating cash flow yield only matters in the real world, but eventually one of large investors is going to catch on that the math doesn't work (and it is only going to get worse...).

As far as sales tax and shorting AMZN goes, it would be best the sales tax does not pass. AMZN has reached agreements with the largest states to collect sales tax. AMZN currently wants EVERYONE to collect sales tax too. The good short deal would be for AMZN to have to collect sales tax and other smaller online retailers don't have to collect sales tax.

Topic.Title: Here it is; Johnny Dirtbag "Movie Star" versus Charlie Sheen---

Message.Msg: "Makes the Da Vinci Code look like nouthin but a pile a deep #$%$ booooooo ssitt"...The New York Times

I want the bill to pass because it will level the playing field and be good for the economy. Right now, we are subsidizing a less efficient system via an artificial tax subsidy. It's good just good policy to pass. Personally, I favor the approach of all the state pension funds going directly after Amazon via their investment assets (exiting any direct or indirect positions) until Amazon collects in their state. They are undermining their own interests if they are invested in Amazon...
